citation.article-title: Butyrivibrio hungatei sp. nov. and Pseudobutyrivibrio xylanivorans sp. nov., butyrate-producing bacteria from the rumen.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Butyrivibrio hungatei sp. nov.
Butyrivibrio hungatei (hun.ga′te.i.N.L. gen. n. hungatei named after Robert E. Hungate, an American microbiologist, who isolated similar strains in the 1960s).
Cells are Gram-negative, straight to slightly curved rods (0·3–0·5×1·5–2·5 μm) that do not form endospores.
Motile by means of a single polar or subpolar flagellum (Fig. 2).
Growth occurs anaerobically at 39 °C, but not at 25 °C.
Limited growth is observed at 45 °C.
No growth is observed in the presence of oxygen.
Arabinose, cellobiose, aesculin, glucose, lactose, maltose, mannose, raffinose, salicin, sucrose and xylose are utilized by the type strain.
Tryptophan, urea and gelatin are not utilized.
The following substrates do not support growth of the type strain: glycerol; mannitol; melezitose; sorbitol; rhamnose; trehalose.
Medium M10 with glucose (22 mM) is fermented to formate (12 mM), acetate (2·2 mM), butyrate (10·8 mM) and ethanol (3·4 mM).
No lactate or succinate production is observed.
No growth occurs in the absence of fermentable carbohydrates.
Does not show any significant fibrolytic or proteolytic activity, utilizing mainly oligo- and monosaccharides as growth substrates.
The type strain does not liquefy gelatin, produce hydrogen sulfide, reduce nitrate or hydrolyse urea and is catalase-negative.
α-Galactosidase, α-arabinosidase, phenylalanine arylamidase and leucine arylamidase are produced.
No amylase, xylanase, β-endoglucanase, laminarinase, pectin hydrolase, proteinase or DNase activities are detected.

The major cellular fatty acid components of strain JK 615T grown in DSM medium no. 330 without rumen fluid are saturated, branched-chain anteiso-C17 : 0 (17·4 %) and iso-C16 : 0 (14·5 %), and unsaturated straight-chain C16 : 1 (13·2 %) fatty acids.
Also present are C16 : 0 2-OH (6·9 %), C14 : 0 2-OH (4·3 %) and iso-C17 : 1 (3·4 %).
Branched-chain fatty acids represent the prevailing proportion of cellular fatty acids in this species.
Strains are common isolates in our set of anaerobic rumen bacteria.
In the rumen, they participate in the utilization of intermediates of fibre degradation.

The type strain is JK 615T (=DSM 14810T =ATCC BAA-456T).
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 44·8 mol% (as determined by the HPLC method).
